title: God's Everlasting Mercy
shortSummary: Psalm 136 is a majestic hymn of thanksgiving that recounts God's mighty acts in creation and history, emphasizing His steadfast mercy that endures forever. This chapter invites believers to remember and praise God's unfailing love demonstrated through His works from the heavens to the deliverance of Israel.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Exodus and Wilderness Wanderings

keyCharacters.name: Israel
keyCharacters.description: God's chosen people, delivered from Egypt and given the Promised Land as an inheritance.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: The Egyptian king who opposed Israel and was defeated by God's mighty hand during the Exodus.

keyCharacters.name: Sihon, king of the Amorites
keyCharacters.description: One of the defeated kings whose land was given to Israel as an inheritance.

keyCharacters.name: Og, king of Bashan
keyCharacters.description: Another defeated king whose territory was granted to Israel, demonstrating God's power over enemies.

definitions.definition: God’s compassionate and steadfast love toward sinners, enduring forever as a foundation of His relationship with His people.
An inheritance or possession passed down, here referring to the land God gave to Israel as a covenant promise.
A biblical metaphor for God’s powerful intervention and deliverance on behalf of His people.
The sun, moon, and stars created by God to govern day and night, demonstrating His wisdom and sovereignty.

outline.heading: Call to Give Thanks for God’s Mercy
outline.description: The psalm opens with a repeated exhortation to thank God, highlighting His goodness and eternal mercy as the foundation for worship.

outline.heading: God’s Creative Power Revealed
outline.description: This section praises God’s wisdom and power in creation, from the heavens and earth to the sun, moon, and stars, emphasizing His sustaining mercy.

outline.heading: God’s Mighty Acts in Deliverance
outline.description: The psalm recounts God’s miraculous deliverance of Israel from Egypt, including the smiting of the firstborn and the crossing of the Red Sea, underscoring His faithful mercy.

outline.heading: God’s Guidance and Victory over Enemies
outline.description: God’s leadership through the wilderness and His defeat of powerful kings who opposed Israel are celebrated as acts of enduring mercy.

outline.heading: God’s Provision and Redemption Remembered
outline.description: The psalm concludes by recalling God’s remembrance of Israel’s low estate, redemption from enemies, and provision of food, culminating in a final call to give thanks to the God of heaven.

application: Regularly express gratitude to God for His enduring mercy, recognizing His goodness in both creation and personal life.
Trust in God’s sovereign power to deliver and guide through difficult circumstances, just as He led Israel.
Remember God’s faithfulness in past blessings as motivation to remain obedient and faithful in present trials.
Celebrate God’s provision daily, acknowledging Him as the source of all sustenance and protection.

keyVerses.text: O give thanks unto the LORD; for he is good: for his mercy endureth for ever.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the tone for the entire psalm, emphasizing God’s goodness and everlasting mercy as reasons for continual thanksgiving.

keyVerses.text: To him that smote Egypt in their firstborn: for his mercy endureth for ever:
keyVerses.significance: It highlights God’s mighty acts of judgment and deliverance, demonstrating His power and mercy in saving His people.

keyVerses.text: Who remembered us in our low estate: for his mercy endureth for ever:
keyVerses.significance: This verse reminds believers that God is mindful of their weakness and lowliness, offering mercy and redemption.

keyVerses.text: O give thanks unto the God of heaven: for his mercy endureth for ever.
keyVerses.significance: The psalm concludes with a universal call to praise God, affirming His mercy as eternal and encompassing all creation.
